items.title: Trump to meet Sharaa at White House, capping major turnaround for Syria
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa's White House meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday caps a stunning year for the rebel-turned-ruler who toppled a longtime autocratic leader and has since toured the world as he seeks to end Syria's international isolation.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa's White House meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday caps a stunning year for the rebel-turned-ruler who toppled a longtime autocratic leader and has since toured the world as he seeks to end Syria's international isolation.

items.title: Syrian President Sharaa makes the 1st White House visit by a Syrian head of state
items.standfirst: President Ahmed al-Sharaa once had ties to al-Qaida and had a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head. Then he led the rebel forces that toppled former Syrian President Bashar al-Assad last year.
items.content: President Ahmed al-Sharaa once had ties to al-Qaida and had a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head. Then he led the rebel forces that toppled former Syrian President Bashar al-Assad last year.(Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)

items.title: Trump 'aims to bring Syria into Abraham Accords' with Sharaa‚Äôs historic White House visit
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa becomes the first Syrian president to visit the White House on Monday, capping an extraordinary turnaround for the former al Qaeda operative who is now leading efforts to end his country‚Äôs international isolation. Sharaa will push for the permanent lifting of sanctions on Syria when he meets with US President Donald Trump, who hopes in return to bring Damascus into the Abraham Accords normalising ties between Israel and several Arab states.
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa becomes the first Syrian president to visit the White House on Monday, capping an extraordinary turnaround for the former al Qaeda operative who is now leading efforts to end his country‚Äôs international isolation. Sharaa will push for the permanent lifting of sanctions on Syria when he meets with US President Donald Trump, who hopes in return to bring Damascus into the Abraham Accords normalising ties between Israel and several Arab states.

items.title: Syrian president to hold talks with Trump at White House
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa is expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil warSyria‚Äôs president, Ahmed al-Sharaa, will on Monday hold talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He is expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. Continue reading...

He is expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy says he wants to ‚Äòprove his innocence‚Äô as he is released from prison
items.standfirst: Former French president, who said his three weeks in jail had been a ‚Äònightmare‚Äô, will serve rest of sentence outside pending appealNicolas Sarkozy has said he wants to ‚Äúprove his innocence‚Äù after being released from prison while he appeals against his conviction for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from Libya.After 20 days in jail that he had earlier described as ‚Äúgruelling‚Äù and a ‚Äúnightmare‚Äù, the former French president was driven away from La Sant√© prison in Paris on Monday accompanied by his wife, the singer Carla Bruni-Sarkozy. items.title: Release of Sarkozy, pending appeal, 'isn't end of sentence: It's morphing into something else'
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy will be released from prison and placed under judicial supervision, a Paris appeals court has ruled, less than three weeks after he began serving a five-year sentence over a scheme to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Annette Young welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy will be released from prison and placed under judicial supervision, a Paris appeals court has ruled, less than three weeks after he began serving a five-year sentence over a scheme to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Annette Young welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.

items.title: Former French president Sarkozy released from prison after three weeks
items.standfirst: The former French president was jailed in October for conspiring to fund his election campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.
items.content: The former French president was jailed in October for conspiring to fund his election campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.

items.title: Sarkozy freed from prison and put under ‚Äòjudicial supervision‚Äô pending appeal ‚Äì as it happened
items.standfirst: Former French president, who is appealing against a conviction for criminal conspiracy, is released from prison in Paris. This live blog is closedAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let‚Äôs take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won‚Äôt be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France‚Äôs highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. The tag has now been removed. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president, who is appealing against a conviction for criminal conspiracy, is released from prison in Paris. This live blog is closedAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let‚Äôs take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won‚Äôt be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France‚Äôs highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. The tag has now been removed. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nicolas Sarkozy was released from prison after serving 20 days.
He was convicted of criminal conspiracy and sentenced to five years.
An appeals court granted his release pending his appeal.
Sarkozy described his time in jail as a "nightmare".
He aims to prove his innocence during the appeal process.

items.title: Car explosion near Red Fort in India's capital kills at least 8 people, police say
items.standfirst: A car exploded near the 17th century Red Fort in New Delhi on Monday, killing at least eight people, injuring others and triggering a fire that damaged vehicles parked nearby, New Delhi police said.
items.content: A car exploded near the 17th century Red Fort in New Delhi on Monday, killing at least eight people, injuring others and triggering a fire that damaged vehicles parked nearby, New Delhi police said.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Eight people die and several injured after car explosion in Delhi, police say
items.standfirst: Several fire engines rushed to the scene after blast reported near the historic Red Fort, fire services saidA car explosion outside the historic Red Fort monument in Delhi has killed at least eight people and started a fire in the surrounding area, according to police.The cause of the explosion, which took place just before 7pm local time (1330 GMT) on Monday night, is being investigated. The registered owner of the car has reportedly been detained for questioning. Continue reading...

items.content: President Trump has pardoned dozens of people who allegedly took part in trying to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election, including "false electors."

items.content: He also pardons his former White House chief of staff, Mark Meadows in a proclamation vowing to "end a grave national injustice".

items.title: Who has President Trump pardoned and why?

items.content: This week, President Trump pardoned allies accused of trying to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It is part of an uptick in "insider pardons" issued in his second term, one legal expert says.(Image credit: Ben Curtis)

items.title: Trump pardons Rudy Giuliani, more than 70 others linked to efforts to overturn 2020 election
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has pardoned scores of his political allies accused of having tried to overturn the results of the 2020 election following Democrat Joe Biden's victory. Trump's former lawyer Rudy Giuliani was among the list of more than 70 people named.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has pardoned scores of his political allies accused of having tried to overturn the results of the 2020 election following Democrat Joe Biden's victory. Trump's former lawyer Rudy Giuliani was among the list of more than 70 people named.

items.title: Trump grants pardons to Giuliani, Meadows, others linked to 2020 election efforts
items.standfirst: The pardons include 77 allies tied to efforts to overturn the 2020 election, including Rudy Giuliani, former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, and former Trump attorney Sidney Powell.
items.content: The pardons include 77 allies tied to efforts to overturn the 2020 election, including Rudy Giuliani, former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, and former Trump attorney Sidney Powell.(Image credit: Seth Wenig/)

ai_summary: President Trump pardoned Rudy Giuliani and Mark Meadows.
The pardons were related to alleged 2020 election interference.
Over 70 people were pardoned in total.
Some pardoned individuals were accused of trying to overturn the election.
The pardons are part of an increase in "insider pardons".

items.title: Typhoon Fung-wong destroys homes in the Philippines

items.content: Evacuees face returning to destroyed homes and flooded streets after Super Typhoon Fung‚ÄëWong hit the Philippines.

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong weakens in the Philippines: Four dead
items.standfirst: One of the year's most powerful storms in the Philippines, Super Typhoon Fung-wong has killed four people, authorities said on Monday, as they began assessing damage after its fury abated, though no reports of major destruction have flowed in yet.
items.content: One of the year's most powerful storms in the Philippines, Super Typhoon Fung-wong has killed four people, authorities said on Monday, as they began assessing damage after its fury abated, though no reports of major destruction have flowed in yet.

items.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Fung-Wong becomes second in a week to hit the Philippines
items.standfirst: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country‚Äôs most populous island. Continue reading...
items.content: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country‚Äôs most populous island. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Speaker Johnson says House will return to Washington for shutdown deal vote

items.content: Seven Democrats and one independent voted with Republicans Sunday night to reopen the US government to end the shutdown.

items.title: Senate takes first step to end record shutdown
items.standfirst: What happened The Senate Sunday night cleared a key first hurdle to ending the record government shutdown, now in its 41st day. Eight Democrats voted with 52 Republicans to proceed with legislation that would fund Congress and a handful of agencies and programs for the full fiscal year and finance‚Ä¶

Eight Democrats voted with 52 Republicans to proceed with legislation that would fund Congress and a handful of agencies and programs for the full fiscal year and finance‚Ä¶

items.title: US Senate shutdown vote: What happened, who voted to end it, what‚Äôs next?
items.standfirst: Some Democrats join Republicans to vote to end the government shutdown, which enters its 41st day.
items.content: Some Democrats join Republicans to vote to end the government shutdown, which enters its 41st day.

items.title: Senators reach deal to reopen the government. And, countries gather for climate talks
items.standfirst: Several Senate Democrats break ranks to join Republicans in a deal to reopen the government. And, world leaders gather in Brazil for a major climate conference, but the U.S. is not expected to attend.
items.content: Several Senate Democrats break ranks to join Republicans in a deal to reopen the government. And, world leaders gather in Brazil for a major climate conference, but the U.S. is not expected to attend.(Image credit: Anna Rose Layden)

ai_summary: Senate Democrats voted to end the government shutdown.
Eight Democrats joined Republicans in the vote.
The Senate took the first step to end the shutdown.
The vote ended the longest government shutdown in history.
The House will vote on the deal.

items.content: The BBC has come under fire over a Panorama documentary that was accused of misleadingly editing a speech by Donald Trump.

The BBC said Director-General Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness had both decided to leave the corporation.

items.content: President Donald Trump has threatened the BBC with legal action after Director-General Tim Davie, and news CEO Deborah Turness resigned.

items.content: Samir Shah has apologised for an "error of judgement" over the editing of a speech by Donald Trump in a BBC Panorama documentary.

items.title: Canada loses measles elimination status after deadly resurgence linked to religious group
items.standfirst: Canada has lost its measles elimination status after almost three decades, health officials said on Monday, citing a persistent resurgence of the virus largely among unvaccinated groups. Canada‚Äôs latest outbreak has lasted for more than a year.
items.content: Canada has lost its measles elimination status after almost three decades, health officials said on Monday, citing a persistent resurgence of the virus largely among unvaccinated groups. Canada‚Äôs latest outbreak has lasted for more than a year.

items.title: Canada loses its measles elimination status. Will the U.S. be next?

items.content: Canada has lost its measles elimination status, the country‚Äôs Public Health Agency announced Monday, because of its inability to control an ongoing outbreak of the virus for at least a year

ai_summary: Canada lost its measles elimination status.
The loss is due to a resurgence of the virus.
The outbreak has lasted for over a year.
The outbreak is linked to unvaccinated groups.
The U.S. is being watched to see if it will be next.
